habitat_description:
Polioptila californica exclusively inhabits coastal sage scrub (Atwood, 1980; Grishaver et al., 1998; Preston et al., 1998; Braden, 1999; Rubinoff, 2001; Harnsworth Associates, 2006). Nests are placed an average of 82 cm above the ground (Grishaver et al., 1998) in California sagebrush, white sage, black sage, lemonadeberry, California buckwheat, California brickellbush, bush penstemon, and Opuntia spp. (Atwood, 1980; Grishaver et al., 1998; Braden, 1999; Sockman, 2000; Harmsworth Associates, 2006).

While some authors also attribute the species to chaparral (e.g., Sockman, 2000) this appears to be only a semantic discrepancy, as the areas that Sockman describes are mapped by GAP as coastal scrub. Furthermore, others specifically note the species’ absence from chaparral habitats (Atwood, 1980; Weaver, 1998). Weaver (1998) further found the species to avoid all areas of dense and/or tall shrubs.

Ninety-seven percent of recorded occurrences were below 500 m in elevation (Atwood and Bolsinger, 1992).

Though Weaver (1998) documented no occurrences in habitat patches < 3 ha, Atwood et al. (1998) detected no minimum patch size requirement, and they specifically found the species in patches of 1 ha (their study’s smallest class size).
